Company: Royal Alliance Associates, SagePoint Financial and FSC Securities Corporation
Description: Three AIG affiliates agreed to pay more than $9.5 million to settle SEC charges that they steered mutual fund clients toward more expensive share classes so the firms could collect higher fees.
Woodbury agreed to pay a $250,000 administrative penalty in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise two of its agents who engaged in fraudulent activities.

Royal Alliance Associates agreed to pay $500,000 to the State of Connecticut in settlement of allegations it failed to adequately supervise its agents and Connecticut office operations, leading to unsuitable securities being sold and fraudulent behavior.
Agency: Connecticut Securities and Business Investments Division

Description: Sagepoint agreed to pay $100,000 to the Investor Education and Protector Fund and $16,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise an investment advisor alleged to have misappropriating client funds. The company's settlement with investors for $700,000 restitution is one of the terms of this Consent Order, so it is included in penalty total.

Woodbury agreed to pay $150,000 to the Investor Education and Protector Fund and $20,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise an investment advisor convicted of fraud for misappropriating client funds. The company's settlement with investors for an estimated $1.9 million in restitution is one of the terms of this Consent Order, so it is included in penalty total.

KMS agreed to pay $975,722 in restitution and up to $50,000 in penalties and costs in settlement of allegations it failed to properly supervise a registered investment adviser who was accused of theft of clients money and promoting a Ponzi Scheme.

Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: The Bureau found that Royal Alliance Associates, Inc. failed to adequately supervise a longtime agent who misappropriated more than $1.4 million from at least three Royal Alliance customers while overseeing a branch office in Maplewood from 2009 to 2017.

Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: American General Securities agreed to pay a total of $215,000 to regulators in Alabama and Mississippi to resolve a case in which one of its representatives engaged in deceptive practices.

The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority ordered 12 firms to pay restitution totaling more than $4 million and fines totaling more than $2.6 million for failing to apply available sales charge discounts to customers' purchases of Unit Investment Trusts (UITs), and related supervisory failures.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) sanctioned and fined two firms - Triad Advisors and Securities America - $650,000 and $625,000, respectively, for failing to supervise the use of consolidated reporting systems resulting in statements with inaccurate valuations being sent to customers, and for failing to retain the consolidated reports in accordance with securities laws.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority sanctioned eight firms and ordered restitution for selling interests in private placement offerings without having a reasonable basis for recommending the securities.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: FINRA fined 25 broker-dealers a total of $2,145,000 for failures related to their completion of FINRA's (then NASD's) firm self-assessment of mutual fund breakpoint discount compliance.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD settled cases against four firms involving mutual fund sales violations.
Info Source: NASD Settles Cases Against MML Investors Services, NYLIFE Securities, Securities America and Northwestern Mutual Investment Services for Fines Totaling over $1.2 Million for Failures Relating to Mutual Fund Sales, States News Service, June 28, 2007 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling $850,000 against four firms for failing to have adequate supervisory systems and procedures to identify opportunities for investors to purchase Class A mutual fund shares at net asset value (NAV), or without a front-end sales charge.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined Securities America, Inc. $2.5 million for failing to adequately supervise a broker who NASD alleged lured long-term employees of Exxon Corporation into retiring prematurely with unreasonable and exaggerated promises of high returns from reinvested funds from their company retirement plans. Securities America was also required to pay $13.8 million in restitution to 32 former Exxon employees.
Info Source: NASD Fines Securities America $2.5 Million, Orders $13.8 Million in Restitution in Investment Scheme Aimed at Exxon Retirees, PR Newswire, September 14, 2006 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined American General Securities, Inc., a member company of American International Group, Inc., more than $1.1 million in connection with its receipt of directed brokerage in return for providing preferential treatment to certain mutual fund companies and for other violations.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD imposed fines totaling more than $34 million on 15 broker-dealers in connection with the receipt of directed brokerage in exchange for preferential treatment for certain mutual fund companies
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD announced that Ladenburg Thalmann & Co. of New York, NY had agreed to refund $1.2 million, plus interest, to customers who were overcharged in proceeds transactions - transactions in which a customer sells securities through a broker and uses the proceeds to pay for other securities purchased at or about the same time.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
